III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications.
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was sexually assaulted by a staff member. Youth are
locked in therapy office to calm down. Staff did not follow-up on
youth banging his head against the wall while in the room. Youth
reported many concerns during placement that went unaddressed.
Investigation Note: This investigation is a continuation of 2023C0000693SI as
Youth A disclosed additional information to Courtesy MDHHS
Worker 1 after the special investigation was already closed.
INTERVIEWS:
The Complainant is this Consultant as this Consultant was
made aware of the information from MDHHS Worker via email
on 9/20/23.
Youth A was interviewed by Courtesy MDHHS Worker 1 on
9/19/23 regarding a complaint from Youth A about an out-of-
state facility. Consultant was not present for the interview as
it was unrelated to 2023C0000693SI. However, during the
interview, Youth A disclosed additional information about
D.A. Blodgett St. John’s. Youth A reported he was placed at the
facility from 2015-2018. Youth A reported staff members (he did
not provide names) were disrespectful and didn’t treat youth
appropriately. Youth A reported he had PTSD because of staff
member’s (he did not provide names) poor treatment while he was
placed there. Youth A reported Staff 1 sexually assaulted him but
was unwilling to provide any further details. Youth A reported he
was afraid Staff 1 did what he did to Youth A in the home to Youth
B as well. Youth A reported Staff 1 treated him differently than
other youth in the home. Youth A reported Staff 1 was “a dick” and
“arrogant” and was always “after them”. Youth A reported there
was a therapy office in the basement, which was a small brick
room with a wooden door and a small window. Youth A reported
Staff 1 would take him to the room and shut him in the room to
calm down. Youth A reported when he was in the room one time,
he slammed his head on the brick wall while staff members (he
didn’t know who) watched him and did nothing about it.
Youth B was interviewed via phone on 9/21/23 in conjunction
with Courtesy MDHHS Worker 2. Youth B reported he was
2

placed at the facility from 2016-2019. Youth B reported he had a
lot of issues and concerns while placed at the facility. He reported
the staff didn’t care, didn’t do their jobs, didn’t follow the rules, did
whatever they wanted. Youth B could not provide any staff
member’s names or specific situations as examples. Youth B
reported he remembered Staff 1 because he had the most issues
with him. Youth B reported “Staff 1 was just problematic. He used
to pick on me and the other kids a lot”. Youth B could not
remember the names of other youth Staff 1 had problems with
except Youth A. Youth B reported Youth A did a lot of bad things.
Youth B reported Youth A made a lot of sexual allegations against
staff members by saying staff members touched his private parts.
Youth B reported he isn’t sure he believes anything like that ever
happened because Youth A was always talking about sexual stuff.
Youth B could not remember which staff members Youth A
alleged sexually touched him. Youth B reported he was put into an
all-brick time out room in the basement of the facility and was left
in there for hours. He reported it happened to other youth too but
couldn’t provide any specifics.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/26/23 in conjunction
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 is no longer employed for the
agency. Staff 1 reported he never made any sexual advances,
had inappropriate conversations or inappropriate contact with any
youth at the facility while he worked there. He reported there were
never any sexual advances or comments made by youth at the
facility towards him either. Staff 1 reported one time Youth A was
in the “time-out room” in the basement at the facility and Youth A
became very upset and banged his head on the wall. Staff 1
reported there were no injuries that he could recall. Staff 1
reported Youth A was very aggressive and frequently attacked
others.
Attempts were made to interview Staff 2 via phone on 10/2/23
and 10/4/23, but Staff 2 did not return contact. Staff 2 is no
longer employed for the agency.
Primary Consultant (PC) was interviewed via phone on
10/3/23. PC worked at the facility from 2011-2013. PC reported
when Youth A and Youth B resided at the facility, seclusion was
allowed per CCI licensing rules. When youth were being unsafe,
they would go to a “time-out room”, which was small room with
cement walls. When PC worked there, staff members were
instructed to help them calm down by standing in the doorway, but
not lock them in there by themselves for long periods of time. It
was used as a space to help youth calm down by getting them
3

away from the milieu and stimulation of the main area with other
youth around.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via phone on
10/3/23. CA began working at the facility in 2018. CA reported the
use of the “time out room” began significantly decreasing after she
began working there. CA reported if the door remained open in the
time-out room, it was considered a “calming space” and the youth
voluntarily stayed in the room while staff helped them process
their emotions. CA reported if the door remained closed, it was
considered seclusion, which could only be 10-15 minutes long at
most. After 10-15 minutes, staff members had to open the door to
allow the youth to try to do better. CA reported the seclusion room
was more traumatic and caused youth to get angrier and more
aggressive, so it was used as a last resort. CA reported they only
utilized it as a seclusion room if staff members had no other way
to keep the youth or staff safe from serious injury.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:
• MDHHS complaints regarding Youth A were reviewed.
Besides this complaint, there are no other complaints about
Youth A being raped or assaulted by any staff members at
the facility.
• Youth A’s chart: There was no documentation Youth A
made any complaints regarding inappropriate staff
interactions with him during the time Youth A was at the
facility.
• Reviewed all of Youth A’s services plans completed during
his placement at the facility. Of note, Youth A has a sexual
abuse history and displayed increased sexualized
behaviors and poor boundaries with staff members and
peers throughout his stay at the facility. There are no notes
of allegations of inappropriate interactions by any staff
members towards Youth A.
• Youth Development Specialist Procedures outlines the
responsibilities for staff to maintain clear and appropriate
boundaries with youth.
• On 10/3/23, CA reported they no longer have Staff 1’s
employee file due to the length of time since he worked
there.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established.
4

There is no evidence to support Youth A was sexually abused by
any staff at the facility. Youth A would not provide further
information besides he was sexually assaulted by Staff 1 and Staff
1 denied having any sexual interactions with Youth A.
When Youth A and Youth B were placed in the facility (2015-
2019), there was a “time-out room” near the therapist offices. The
“time-out room” was utilized for youth to voluntarily calm down or
for seclusions, which were both approved methods during the
timeframe the youth were placed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Resident Restraint
Section (2) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Note: When Youth A and Youth B were placed at the facility, this
is the rule that was ineffect.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff member kicked youth's feet from out under him during a
restraint resulting in youth hitting their face on the ground.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed by Courtesy MDHHS Worker 1 on
9/19/23 regarding a complaint from Youth A about an out-of-
state facility. Consultant was not present for the interview as
it was unrelated to 2023C0000693SI. However, during the
interview, Youth A disclosed additional information about
D.A. Blodgett St. John’s. Youth A reported one time Staff 1 was
assisting in restraining him due to behaviors, and Staff 1 kicked
Youth A’s feet from under him, which resulted in Youth A hitting
his face on the ground.
Youth B was interviewed via phone on 9/21/23 in conjunction
with Courtesy MDHHS Worker 2. Youth B reported staff
members used to put him in restraints all the time for no reason,
they were long restraints, and he wasn’t even showing aggressive
behaviors prior to the restraints occurring. Youth B could not
provide any staff names or specific scenarios. Youth B reported
the restraints weren’t ever done right, so he got hurt, but no one
5

believed he was hurt. Youth B reported staff members (couldn’t
provide names) slammed youth on the ground, slammed youth
into walls, and “did everything wrong”.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 9/26/23 in conjunction
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 is no longer employed for the
agency. Staff 1 reported he does not remember any youth being
injured while he was restraining them. Staff 1 reported he never
completed any restraints using moves outside of what they were
taught in CPI. Staff 1 reported if there were ever any injuries
during any restraints at the facility, it was a big deal and there was
an internal investigation completed along with an investigation
completed by MDHHS and DCWL. Staff 1 reported there were
never any situations he was a part of or he saw involving a youth’s
face being near the ground, or kicking a youth’s feet out from
under them.
Attempts were made to interview Staff 2 via phone on 10/2/23
and 10/4/23, but Staff 2 did not return contact. Staff 2 is no
longer employed for the agency.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:
• Reviewed all Special Investigation allegations and findings
for all special investigation reports completed for the facility
between 7/1/16-12/31/19 due to allegations by Youth A and
Youth B that staff conducted inappropriate restraints. The
findings are as follows:
o 2018C0208031 dated 4/3/18 alleges Youth A
received bruises while being restrained by Staff 3.
During interviews, Youth A reported he felt safe at
the facility and liked it at the facility. Youth A couldn't
remember where he received the bruise and didn't
have any concerns. Video footage was reviewed &
restraint was conducted appropriately. No violation
established.
o SI 2017C0208056 dated 10/16/17 alleges Youth B
was inappropriately restrained causing injury to his
shoulder. The violation was established because
Staff 4 restrained Youth B when he shouldn’t have.
However, the restraint was done properly, and SIR
notes injury was likely due to Youth B kicking his
legs up and twisting his body to free himself. A CAP
was approved on 10/20/17.
o SI 2018C0103036 dated 8/30/18 alleges Youth B
was inappropriately touched by Staff 5 during a
restraint. No violation was established.
6

o SI 2018C0103045 dated 12/26/18 alleges Staff 6
improperly restrained Youth B and made
inappropriate comments to him. In Youth B’s
interview, he said there was nothing he liked about
the facility, he felt unsafe, but couldn't or wouldn't
give further details. A violation was established
regarding Staff 6 making inappropriate comments,
but not regarding conducting an improper restraint.
o SI 2019C0103027 dated 7/15/19 alleges Staff 7
ridiculed and unwarrantedly restrained Youth B.
Violation was established and a CAP was approved
on 8/30/19.
• On 10/3/23, CA reported they no longer have Staff 1’s
employee file due to the length of time since he worked
there.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. Youth A provided minimal details
about Staff 1 conducting an improper restraint and Youth B did not
provide specific details about circumstances and/or staff involved
in improper restraints. Therefore, based on Consultant’s review of
all SIRs completed from 7/1/16-12/31/19, it is determined these
concerns were previously addressed. Staff 1 reported he
completed all restraints per his training. He reported if restraints at
the facility were ever done improperly or youth received injuries
during restraints, it was a big deal, and they were investigated by
MDHHS and DCWL.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings, the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended to continue the current licensing
status.
